tailed in Tables 4-15. The frequency with which diarrhea and respiratory

The most impressive clinical finding is that in every district marasmus
Urine only
and prekwashiorkor were diagnosed clinically as occurring within 1.2 to 6.1
Blood only
percent of boys and 3.5 to 12.1 percent of the girls examined. In this re-
gard it is to be noted that the weaning age of girls tends to be some 2 months
younger than that of boys. It is reasonable to suggest a relationship between
this practice and the sex differences in malnutrition. Kwashiorkor was diag-
nosed in 0.4-1.2 percent of the children in all districts except Hebron, where
References
it was not recorded. In the Hebron district, however, both marasmus and pre-
kwashiorkor were common.
Interdepartmental Committee on Nutrition for National Defense. The
Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan - Nutrition Survey, Washington, D. C.,
Perusal of Tables 4-15 reveals that up to some 10 percent of the children
examined were judged clinically to appear weak or to exhibit bad nutriture,
Manual for Nutrition Surveys, 2d edition, Washington, D.C.,
the highest incidence of such findings usually being in infants under 30 months
of age. Changes in the texture and color of the hair indicative of malnutri-
tion, angular lesions of the lips consistent with ariboflavinosis, and muscular
wasting were all signs commonly encountered. Again these evidences of under-
nutrition were more consistently present in the age groups up to 30 months, but
were not limited to the younger children. The frequent occurrence of these clin-
ical signs indicates that malnutrition is more widely encountered in the popula-
tion than is indicated by the figures for full-blown states of protein-Calorie
malnutrition, i.e., kwashiorkor and marasmus.
These data emphasize the relative importance of marasmus and prekwashiorkor
and of kwashiorkor as public health problems within the preschool population.
The former syndromes occur 5 to 10 or more times as frequently as does the lat-
ter. Pediatricians and public health workers often have paid too little atten-
tion to the first-named types of protein-Calorie malnutrition because of the
wide interest and emphasis on kwashiorkor in recent years. The total spectrum
of protein-Calorie malnutrition, the milder forms, the moderately severe, the
extreme states of both marasmus and kwashiorkor, all must be considered in order
properly to assess the magnitude and seriousness of malnutrition among infants.
In order better to understand the nature of the severe protein-Calorie mal-
nutrition (marasmus, prekwashiorkor, kwashiorkor), the weights and heights of
children on whom this diagnosis was made at various ages up to three years have
been individually compared with the mean values for the total group in the sur-
vey (Figures 5-8). It is evident that at all ages and both sexes the children
in whom these diagnoses were made were almost invariably below the mean of the
total group in weight, and similarly though less strikingly retarded in height.
The cases of prekwashiorkor and kwashiorkor cluster about the 10th percentile of
the survey group in weight; the cases of marasmus fall even below this level
(Figures 9 and 10).
